_exec_summary.SummaryText:
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Haviland Products Company is a leader among small, chemical manufacturer and distributors in its environmental, health and safety programs.  Our commitment to protect our employees and the communities that are home to our operations is an integral part of Haviland's way of doing business.  Haviland has established environmental, health, safety and emergency response policies and standards to meet or exceed all regulatory requirements.  As a member of the National Association of Chemical Distributors (NACD), Haviland subscribes to the codes established for Responsible Distribution.



THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED



The Kalamazoo facility has one process that involves regulated substances.



The Kalamazoo facility Hydrazine Hydrate 100% unloading process involves unloading and packaging of Hydrazine Hydrate 100%, which is to be used in boiler water treatment applications.  The regulated substance involved with this process is Hydrazine Hydrate 100%.



WORST-CASE RELEASE SCENARIO AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO



The toxic worst-case scenario is the catastrophic failure of a 5,000 gallon portable Isotainer and the release of 40,000 lbs. of Hydrazine Hydrate 100%.  The evaporating Hydrazine Hydrate 100% could reach offsite endpoints and nearby public receptors.



There is not a flammable worst-case scenario for the same catastrophic failure of the 5,000 gallon Isotainer due to the flashpoint of the regulated substance to be 165A?F.



The toxic alternative case scenario is a ruptured hose during the unloading process, which could result in the release of 4,700 lbs. of the regulated substance to containment.  The evaporating Hydrazine Hydrate 100% could reach offsite endpoints and nearby public receptors.



There is not a flammable worst-case scenario for the same ruptured hose scenario due to the flashpoint of the regulated substance to be 165A?F.



THE GENERAL ACCIDENT

AL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



Haviland's general accidental release prevention program includes:



-EPA 40 CFR 68 - Risk Management Plan

-OSHA 29 CFR 1910.120 - Hazardous Waste Operations & Emergency Response

-Other EPA, OSHA, DOT and State regulations

-Generally recognized & accepted engineering codes and standards, and

-Haviland Environmental, Health and Safety standards



The following engineering and administrative controls help prevent a release of Hydrazine Hydrate 100%:



-the material is stored in an above ground Isotainer tank

-the unloading operation is constantly manned and only done in daylight hours

-the personnel performing the unloading are well trained and have 10+ years experience

-the indoor unloading area has both oxygen and hydrazine gas detection equipment



5-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no incidents at the Kalamazoo facility that meet the criteria for reporting in the five-year accident history.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Haviland's Emergency Response Plan incorporates OSHA's Incident Command System, as defined in 29 CFR 1910.120(q).  In the event of an emergency requiring assistance form the outside, our personnel will make the necessary notifications and will be able to interact effectively with outside emergency response personnel.  Working with Haviland Emergency Response Team members, the Kalamazoo Department of Public Safety and Kalamazoo County LEPC would make any decisions concerning how best to protect the neighboring community.



In the event of a release of our one regulated substance, or other hazardous material, Haviland's Emergency Response Team would use chemical-specific response plans and procedures to address the emergency at the earliest stage possible so as to prevent escalation of the incident.



Contracted professional technicians test our fire protection system, which includes signals, alarms and sprinkler protection of all processing areas, on a an

nual basis.  



Facility personnel test our safety showers and eyewash stations on a monthly basis.



The Emergency Response Team is provided training on emergency response procedures and use of protective and response equipment, and participate in training excercises at least annually.  We currently have eleven members trained to the HAZMAT Technician or Specialist levels.  The Emergency Response Team maintains the chemical protective clothing and response equipment.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Haviland is constantly striving to upgrade its processes, control technology, employee training, inspection, repair and maintenance of process equipment in order to improve safety.
